danfulea.math.numerical

Class RootFind

  • java.lang.Object
    • danfulea.math.numerical.RootFind

  • public class RootFind
extends java.lang.Object
    Root finding class Based on literature, including Numerical Recipes in C (Cambridge Univ.).
    Author:
    Dan Fulea, 10 OCT. 2006

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Static Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void balanc(double[][] a, int n)
      Given a matrix a[1..n][1..n], this routine replaces it by a balanced matrix with identical eigenvalues.
      static double[] birge(double[] a)
      Given the coefficients of the polynomial (usually used in interpolation), this routine calculates the roots using Birge-Viette method.
      void broydn(double[] x, int n)
      Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, find the root by Broyden’s method embedded in a globally convergent strategy.
      double[][] fdjac(int n, double[] x, double[] fvec)
      Computes forward-difference approximation to Jacobian.
      double fmin(double[] x)
      Returns f = 1/2 F · F at x.
      void hqr(double[][] a, int n, double[] wr, double[] wi)
      Finds all eigenvalues of an upper Hessenberg matrix a[1..n][1..n].
      double Iter(double x)
      Successive iterations for solution refinement.
      void laguer(Complex[] a, int m, Complex x)
      Given the degree m and the m+1 complex coefficients a[0..m] of the polynomial sum from i=0 to m of a[i]x^i, and given a complex value x, this routine improves x by Laguerre’s method until it converges, within the achievable roundoff limit, to a root of the given polynomial.
      void lnsrch(int n, double[] xold, double fold, double[] g, double[] p, double[] x, double stpmax, java.lang.String namS)
      Given an n-dimensional point xold[1..n], the value of the function and gradient there, fold and g[1..n], and a direction p[1..n], finds a new point x[1..n] along the direction p from xold where the function func has decreased “sufficiently.” The new function value is returned in f.
      double localFunc(double[] x, java.lang.String s)
      Used internally.
      void mnewt(int ntrial, double[] x, int n, double tolx, double tolf)
      Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, take ntrial Newton-Raphson steps to improve the root.
      void newt(double[] x, int n)
      Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, find the root by a globally convergent Newton’s method.
      void qroot(double[] p, int n, double b, double c, double eps)
      Given n+1 coefficients p[0..n] of a polynomial of degree n, and trial values for the coefficients of a quadratic factor x*x+b*x+c, improve the solution until the coefficients b,c change by less than eps.
      double rtbis(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using bisection, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2.
      double rtflsp(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using the false position method, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2.
      double rtnewt(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of a function known to lie in the interval [x1, x2].
      double rtsafe(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using a combination of Newton-Raphson and bisection, find the root of a function bracketed between x1 and x2.
      double rtsec(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using the secant method, find the root of a function func thought to lie between x1 and x2.
      double Secant(double a, double b)
      Another implementation for secant method.
      void set_defaults()
      3 digits number format.
      static double SIGN(double a, double b)
      Change the sign of a if b is negative!
      private static double[] trunc(double[] xx)
      Used internally.
      boolean validate()
      Check if the root finding method succeeds.
      int zbrac(double x1, double x2)
      Given a function func and an initial guessed range x1 to x2, the routine expands the range geometrically until a root is bracketed by the returned values x1_zbrac and x2_zbrac (in which case zbrac returns 1) or until the range becomes unacceptably large (in which case zbrac returns 0).
      void zbrak(double x1, double x2, int n, double[] xb1, double[] xb2)
      Given a function fx defined on the interval from x1-x2 subdivide the interval into n equally spaced segments, and search for zero crossings of the function.
      double zbrent(double x1, double x2, double tol)
      Using Brent’s method, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2.
      void zrhqr(double[] a, int m, double[] rtr, double[] rti)
      Find all the roots of a polynomial with real coefficients, sum from i=0 to m of a(i)x^i, given the degree m and the coefficients a[0..m].
      double zriddr(double x1, double x2, double xacc)
      Using Ridders’ method, return the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2.
      void zroots(Complex[] a, int m, Complex[] roots, int polish)
      Given the degree m and the m+1 complex coefficients a[0..m] of the polynomial sum from i=0 to m of a(i)x^i, this routine successively calls laguer and finds all m complex roots in roots[1..m].

        Change the sign of a if b is negative!

      • zbrac

        public int zbrac(double x1,
                 double x2)
        Given a function func and an initial guessed range x1 to x2, the routine expands the range geometrically until a root is bracketed by the returned values x1_zbrac and x2_zbrac (in which case zbrac returns 1) or until the range becomes unacceptably large (in which case zbrac returns 0).
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        Returns:
        the result

      • zbrak

        public void zbrak(double x1,
                  double x2,
                  int n,
                  double[] xb1,
                  double[] xb2)
        Given a function fx defined on the interval from x1-x2 subdivide the interval into n equally spaced segments, and search for zero crossings of the function. nb is input as the maximum number of roots sought, and is reset to the number of bracketing pairs xb1[1..nb], xb2[1..nb] that are found.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        n - n
        xb1 - xb1
        xb2 - xb2

      • rtbis

        public double rtbis(double x1,
                    double x2,
                    double xacc)
        Using bisection, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2. The root, returned as rtbis, will be refined until its accuracy is ±xacc.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • rtflsp

        public double rtflsp(double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
        Using the false position method, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2. The root, returned as rtflsp, is refined until its accuracy is ±xacc.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • rtsec

        public double rtsec(double x1,
                    double x2,
                    double xacc)
        Using the secant method, find the root of a function func thought to lie between x1 and x2. The root, returned as rtsec, is refined until its accuracy is ±xacc.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • zriddr

        public double zriddr(double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
        Using Ridders’ method, return the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2. The root, returned as zriddr, will be refined to an approximate accuracy xacc.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • zbrent

        public double zbrent(double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double tol)
        Using Brent’s method, find the root of a function func known to lie between x1 and x2. The root, returned as zbrent, will be refined until its accuracy is tol.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        tol - tol
        Returns:
        the result

      • rtnewt

        public double rtnewt(double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
        Using the Newton-Raphson method, find the root of a function known to lie in the interval [x1, x2]. The root rtnewt will be refined until its accuracy is known within ±xacc. funcd is a user-supplied routine that returns both the function value and the first derivative of the function at the point x.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • rtsafe

        public double rtsafe(double x1,
                     double x2,
                     double xacc)
        Using a combination of Newton-Raphson and bisection, find the root of a function bracketed between x1 and x2. The root, returned as the function value rtsafe, will be refined until its accuracy is known within ±xacc. funcd is a user-supplied routine that returns both the function value and the first derivative of the function.
        Parameters:
        x1 - x1
        x2 - x2
        xacc - xacc
        Returns:
        the result

      • laguer

        public void laguer(Complex[] a,
                   int m,
                   Complex x)
        Given the degree m and the m+1 complex coefficients a[0..m] of the polynomial sum from i=0 to m of a[i]x^i, and given a complex value x, this routine improves x by Laguerre’s method until it converges, within the achievable roundoff limit, to a root of the given polynomial. The number of iterations taken is returned as its.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        m - m
        x - x

      • zroots

        public void zroots(Complex[] a,
                   int m,
                   Complex[] roots,
                   int polish)
        Given the degree m and the m+1 complex coefficients a[0..m] of the polynomial sum from i=0 to m of a(i)x^i, this routine successively calls laguer and finds all m complex roots in roots[1..m]. The boolean variable polish should be input as true (1) if polishing (also by Laguerre’s method) is desired, false (0) if the roots will be subsequently polished by other means.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        m - m
        roots - roots
        polish - polish

      • balanc

        public void balanc(double[][] a,
                   int n)
        Given a matrix a[1..n][1..n], this routine replaces it by a balanced matrix with identical eigenvalues. A symmetric matrix is already balanced and is unaffected by this procedure. The parameter RADIX should be the machine’s floating-point radix.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n

      • hqr

        public void hqr(double[][] a,
                int n,
                double[] wr,
                double[] wi)
        Finds all eigenvalues of an upper Hessenberg matrix a[1..n][1..n]. On input a can be exactly as output from elmhes (see Eigensystem), on output it is destroyed. The real and imaginary parts of the eigenvalues are returned in wr[1..n] and wi[1..n], respectively.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        n - n
        wr - wr
        wi - wi

      • zrhqr

        public void zrhqr(double[] a,
                  int m,
                  double[] rtr,
                  double[] rti)
        Find all the roots of a polynomial with real coefficients, sum from i=0 to m of a(i)x^i, given the degree m and the coefficients a[0..m]. The method is to construct an upper Hessenberg matrix whose eigenvalues are the desired roots, and then use the routines balanc and hqr. The real and imaginary parts of the roots are returned in rtr[1..m] and rti[1..m], respectively.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        m - m
        rtr - rtr
        rti - rti

      • birge

        public static double[] birge(double[] a)
        Given the coefficients of the polynomial (usually used in interpolation), this routine calculates the roots using Birge-Viette method.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        Returns:
        the result

      • trunc

        private static double[] trunc(double[] xx)
        Used internally.
        Parameters:
        xx - xx
        Returns:
        the result

      • qroot

        public void qroot(double[] p,
                  int n,
                  double b,
                  double c,
                  double eps)
        Given n+1 coefficients p[0..n] of a polynomial of degree n, and trial values for the coefficients of a quadratic factor x*x+b*x+c, improve the solution until the coefficients b,c change by less than eps. The routine poldiv (see EvalFunc class) is used.
        Parameters:
        p - p
        n - n
        b - b
        c - c
        eps - eps

      • fdjac

        public double[][] fdjac(int n,
                        double[] x,
                        double[] fvec)
        Computes forward-difference approximation to Jacobian. On input, x[1..n] is the point at which the Jacobian is to be evaluated, fvec[1..n] is the vector of function values at the point, and vecfunc(n,x,f) is a user-supplied routine that returns the vector of functions at x. On output, df[1..n][1..n] is the Jacobian array.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        x - x
        fvec - fvec
        Returns:
        the result

      • fmin

        public double fmin(double[] x)
        Returns f = 1/2 F · F at x. The vecfunc is a routine that returns the vector of functions at x. It is set to point to a user-supplied routine in the calling program. Global variables also communicate the function values back to the calling program.
        Parameters:
        x - x
        Returns:
        the result

      • mnewt

        public void mnewt(int ntrial,
                  double[] x,
                  int n,
                  double tolx,
                  double tolf)
        Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, take ntrial Newton-Raphson steps to improve the root. Stop if the root converges in either summed absolute variable increments tolx or summed absolute function values tolf.
        Parameters:
        ntrial - ntrial
        x - x
        n - n
        tolx - tolx
        tolf - tolf

      • localFunc

        public double localFunc(double[] x,
                        java.lang.String s)
        Used internally.
        Parameters:
        x - x
        s - s
        Returns:
        the result

      • lnsrch

        public void lnsrch(int n,
                   double[] xold,
                   double fold,
                   double[] g,
                   double[] p,
                   double[] x,
                   double stpmax,
                   java.lang.String namS)
        Given an n-dimensional point xold[1..n], the value of the function and gradient there, fold and g[1..n], and a direction p[1..n], finds a new point x[1..n] along the direction p from xold where the function func has decreased “sufficiently.” The new function value is returned in f. stpmax is an input quantity that limits the length of the steps so that you do not try to evaluate the function in regions where it is undefined or subject to overflow. p is usually the Newton direction. The output quantity check is false (0) on a normal exit. It is true (1) when x is too close to xold. In a minimization algorithm, this usually signals convergence and can be ignored. However, in a zero-finding algorithm the calling program should check whether the convergence is spurious.
        Parameters:
        n - n
        xold - xold
        fold - fold
        g - g
        p - p
        x - x
        stpmax - stpmax
        namS - namS pointing to fmin via localFunc

      • newt

        public void newt(double[] x,
                 int n)
        Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, find the root by a globally convergent Newton’s method. The vector of functions to be zeroed, called fvec_newt in the routine below, is returned by the user-supplied routine. The output quantity check is false (0) on a normal return and true (1) if the routine has converged to a local minimum of the function fmin defined below. In this case try restarting from a different initial guess.
        Parameters:
        x - x
        n - n

      • broydn

        public void broydn(double[] x,
                   int n)
        Given an initial guess x[1..n] for a root in n dimensions, find the root by Broyden’s method embedded in a globally convergent strategy. The vector of functions to be zeroed, called fvec_newt in the routine below, is returned by the user-supplied routine. The routine fdjac and the function fmin from newt are used. The output quantity check is false (0) on a normal return and true (1) if the routine has converged to a local minimum of the function fmin or if Broyden’s method can make no further progress. In this case try restarting from a different initial guess.
        Parameters:
        x - x
        n - n

      • set_defaults

        public void set_defaults()
        3 digits number format.

      • validate

        public boolean validate()
        Check if the root finding method succeeds.
        Returns:
        the result

      • Secant

        public double Secant(double a,
                     double b)
        Another implementation for secant method. Find the root of user supplied function in [a,b] interval.
        Parameters:
        a - a
        b - b
        Returns:
        the result

      • Iter

        public double Iter(double x)
        Successive iterations for solution refinement.
        Parameters:
        x - x, the gross solution or initial guess.
        Returns:
        the result
